The neighborhood is now listed in the National Register of Historic Places. Duval County Registry shows plans by other surveyors for this development.

column7: Plan of Estate of E. Reddington Mudge

column18: Subtitled: Showing street numbers, houses and lots with their widths and owners names to date. Also assessors valuation of vacant land per foot for 1886." Plan showing Lots A and B with area shown in Sq. ft or acres; outline of roads, buildings, and pond. Notations for ledge and gravel hill. Subtitle says "Produced from plan of John C. Haskell, surveyor dated 1874."
column19: Per 1880s Hopkins Atlas, the Mudge estate was a vast tract in southwest Swampscott. Per Richards 1905, property had become fully developed. Owner was Enoch Redington Mudge (1812 - 1881). He was the son of the first native New England Methodist preacher and became a wealthy Boston merchant and philanthropist. The 130+ acre estate in Swampscott was his summer home. The estate was subdivided according to a plan by Olmsted (https://www.swampscottma.gov/historical-commission/pages/olmsted-historic-district-swampscott-massachusetts). The land was sold to the Swampscott Land Trust who hired Olmsted.

column18: Street layout showing bridge routes over Charles River, which is rendered with elevation lines. Table provided on comparison of distances of bridges for 4 routes over the river. Table contains statement: The Brookline Bridge route is the shortest and cheapest for any citizen of Cambridge, not better accommodated by Harvard Bridge, to reach Boston, South Boston, Roxbury, Dorchester, and as good to reach Brookline as the upper or Magazine Street Bridge. Includes street alongside river leading to Metropolitan Park and Soldier's Field but under Magazine Street. On Cambridge side, dotted line shows Fort Washington Park Way by Windsor Street to Cambridge Field and Middlesex Fells, with substitute path entering river drive Brookline Avenue vis Washington and Hastings Square. Note mentions Putnam Avenue as having car line from Harvard Square to Harvard Bridge.
column19: In 1890s, efforts made to replace old wooden bridge with newer construction, involving negotiations between Boston and Cambridge.  Parkway had been proposed from Pearl Street to Middlesex Fells.

Facsimile of Office of city clerk's stamp indicates that plan was approved 1899-11-23 for widening of Albany Street and derived from "Streets of City of Cambridge" Volume 15, Sheet 6.
column19: Lewis M. Hastings (1853-1936) was influential city engineer in late 19th-century Cambridge.

column18: Copy of plan and elevations of Pacific Street. Plan shows reference measurements and location of abutters and building footprints, including detailed footprint of stable, barrel factory, and attached sheds and steps. Elevations show reference points and heights between city base and established grade.  Note from City engineer states Pacific Street extending from Albany Street is "free from encroachment upon its lines." Plan derived from "Streets of City of Cambridge" Volume 7, Sheet 27.
column19: Edwin F. Bowker (1840-1924) was a city engineer in late 19th-century Cambridge before founding his own firm; his papers are part of the BPL's Perkins Collection.
